narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a broad overview of different pathophysiological mechanisms that could occur in the body, and learned to think about pathophysiology from both mechanistic/detailed and conceptual/thematic perspectives. Additionally, I learned about experimental techniques used both in the laboratory and in the clinic.
You learn pretty niche knowledge relating to specific dimensions of pathobiology. I learned a lot about blood, the kidneys, the brain, and cancer -- and not much else.
So much
I learned a lot about what medical school would feel like with rotating professors and a large span of topic to cover in such short amount of time. I also learned how to answer questions thoroughly.
Pathology of various organ systems (renal, nervous) as well as an array of other diseases (cancers).
a lot of pathology knowledge!
I learned all about pathobiology and how to understand disease in the body. There were several basic principles that comprised the course that I appreciated.
I learned so much taking this course - we touched every surface of pathobiology and the fundamentals of all aspects.
I learned about the molecular basis, pathobiological applications, and treatments in five areas of medicine: cellular injury,  hematology, neurology, cancer, and nephrology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The frequent midterms of the course mean that you have to really keep up with your studying to do well. I liked this format because it kept me accountable but also meant that I am currently not stressing heading into the "final" (which is just a non-cumulative midterm, essentially). The fact that there were 5 professors meant that I got a good sense of each specific field from an expert. The downside of the rotating teaching staff, however, is that I had to "relearn" how I took tests on every single midterm, and the professors varied in how much extra content (notes, practice problems, or at one point whether they posted slides or not) they gave to help us study. Standardizing this would be really helpful. Also, no midterm feedback was provided so I had no idea what I got right/wrong.

A lot of the professors are doctors and are thus not super experienced with teaching undergraduates (and teaching on zoom at all? Half of them messed up the zoom recordings which was annoying). Some of the information in lecture was super detailed and it was unclear what would be tested. 

That said, it was cool to have a revolving door of professors that each had extensive knowledge in their own area of expertise. But the class as a whole did lack a sense of cohesiveness.

Weaknesses: the slides of most professors were all over the place, the course lacked organization, and there seemed to be very little communication between the prof and the TAs. We also couldn't see which questions we got wrong on exams which is annoying because it prevents us from finding out what we could've improved.
Great strengths

Strengths: I think this course contained really interesting content, and all the professors were super engaging.

Weaknesses: I wished the course could be a little bit more structured in terms of streamlining resources. I would also wish that the professors would do better job of providing the TAs with resources so they could know what to expect from us and what we should expect on the exams. I also wish I would get more timely feedback on my exams so I know what not to do during the next exam.
This class is a great introduction/survey into pathology, but can start to feel like an endless list of diseases to memorize at times.
Better organization, better test prep
I liked that it was different units with different professors, but the difference in exam style and difficulty made it hard to study.
This course was run very well, but was very, very heavy with content. It was difficult to learn so much information in 4-5 lecture sections.

The material was super interesting and all the professors were quite knowledgeable. The issue with having so many different professors is that there is a lack of continuity in course materials/what's expected on exams. It would have been nice to have been able to see our exams and how they were graded. Even if they weren't used for a grade, it also would have been nice to have practice questions to work on between exams.

I think a strength of the course is its content; it is both extremely interesting and very detailed. I felt I learned a lot in such a short amount of time, with many applications to a future career in biology or medicine. One weakness is the application of the content. While we learned a lot in each lecture module, it felt as if we were on our own for the exams, and you never knew what to expect.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not all of the courses were recorded because the professors weren't sure where the files went once they press record. If it's possible to pre-link the Zoom links to the course to the Canvas Zoom page so that it autouploads into the media file, that would be really helpful.
Great
I think the professors all had trouble with technology. I wished this course had a UTA. Course may be extremely better in person.
Recorded lectures should always be used.
The recorded lectures were really helpful, especially as the material was quite dense.
The course was run very well virtually.

The recording of the zoom lectures was a very good practice, but the consistency was lacking. It felt like every other week there was some technical difficulty that kept us from watching the lecture, even though they told us each class would be recorded and uploaded in a timely fashion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this is a great course if you're interested in the combination of immunology with physiology. If you're only taking this for an MCDB credit though, the frequent midterms might not be worth it, especially since it's not a 350+ course that would count as a special seminar.

It's a very average MCDB elective. Looking back, I am not sure if I learned anything super important (just niche knowledge in different areas of pathology). But the exams are not too difficult and none of them are cumulative so the class as a whole is not so bad. It did not change my life by any means. My main grievance is that the class lacked a sense of cohesiveness. But like it was ok as a class because it had such a regular rhythm: ignore lecture for two weeks, cram everything two nights before the midterm, repeat.
No.
Yes

If youre interested in learning about pathology and dont mind some rote memorization, yes! The lecturers vary in their ability to make the material engaging, so be ready for some modules to be pretty boring.
yes!
Only if you want a very basic overview of the subject. Test questions are sometimes overwhelming.
Yes! I really liked the material and found the lectures to generally be very engaging, though I think the experience would be very different in person.
Good class to take if you're pre-med

Not really. I'm a premed student and I thought this class would be interesting, but I only enjoyed 2/5 units of the course, in the rest I felt like I didn't learn very much and was just straight memorizing for the exams.
Yes - you must be prepared to have to dedicate a lot of time to studying for the course, but it was very worth it.
I would definitely recommend it if you were pre-med because so much is taught that it is a good foundation for a greater foray into these topics.
